commitResults.messageTitle: Level-1
commitResults.messageBody: Add functionality to greet and bid farewell to user

commitResults.messageTitle: Enable chatbot to echo user commands
commitResults.messageBody:
Modified the chatbot to repeat user input
and exit when the user says "bye".
This change allows the chatbot to mimic user commands
as a basic interactive feature.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add task management functionality to Fenix
commitResults.messageBody:
Added the ability for Fenix to store and list user tasks.
Improved structure by separating concerns
with methods for greeting and bidding farewell,
accepting, getting and processing user input,
storing tasks and showing all tasks.
Modified the output format to differentiate between
user commands and Fenix's responses when modifications
are made.

commitResults.messageTitle: Implement task completion and marking tasks as undone in Fenix
commitResults.messageBody:
Introduced the ability to mark tasks as done or not done.
Added a new Task class to encapsulate task-related data and behavior.
Enhanced the Fenix class to handle task marking and unmarking commands.
Updated the task list display to reflect task completion status.
Implemented input validation for task indexing to ensure valid commands.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add support for ToDo, Deadline, and Event task types and refactor using inheritance to improve code quality
commitResults.messageBody:
- Introduced three new task types: ToDo, Deadline, and Event.
  - ToDo: Tracks tasks without a specific date or time.
  - Deadline: Tracks tasks that need to be completed by a certain date.
  - Event: Tracks tasks that span a start and end date or time.
  - Enhanced the `list` command to display tasks with the appropriate type labels and deadlines.
- Refactored task structure using inheritance:
  - Created a base `Task` class to encapsulate common behavior for all task types (e.g., `markAsDone`, `unmarkAsDone`, and status tracking).
  - `ToDo`, `Deadline`, and `Event` classes inherit from `Task`, reusing common functionality and reducing code duplication.
  - Enhanced the `Deadline` and `Event` classes to handle date and time-specific functionality, while leveraging shared behavior from `Task`.
- Improved code quality:
  - Modularized input processing logic into helper methods (new `markAsDone`, `unmarkAsDone`, and `processTasks` methods).
  - Enhanced error handling to provide clear feedback for invalid user input.

commitResults.messageTitle: Handle errors
commitResults.messageBody:
Added support to handle the following errors:
- No task provided for addition (throws error in case of deadline and event types as
  you cannot split a null task string to get the deadlines - split error)
- Task input format is erroneous (not enough /'s in the case of deadline and event task types -
  array index out of bounds error when you try to access the 'deadlines')

Added support to respond with corresponding warning messages
for the following invalid input cases:
- Invalid command
- Empty task name field (in the case of deadline and event task types)

commitResults.messageTitle: Clean up code and add new Fenix Exception class
commitResults.messageBody:
Code cleanup:
- Organised all the constant strings into a new interface
  which is implemented by the Fenix class
- Decomposed some of the longer return strings into
  a combination of smaller, more descriptive chunks
  using variables

Excetptions added:
- Added a new Fenix Exception class to handle invalid
  inputs which do not necessarily cause errors
- Added extra try-catch blocks such as in the methods to
  mark and unmark tasks

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'branch-Level-5'
Add test case to ensure code functions as expected
Change the data structure for storing tasks
commitResults.messageBody:
Implemented the usage of the Java Collections classes.
Replaced the primitive normal array which was used for
storing tasks with the ArrayList<Task> collection which
makes it easier to find, add, delete tasks and also
dynamically change the size of the array

commitResults.messageTitle: Modify user input processing loop and delete dead code
commitResults.messageBody:
Deleted two methods and replaced their functionalities with
new code under the processUserInput method

commitResults.messageTitle: Delete tasks
commitResults.messageBody:
Added functionality to delete tasks,
extracted a getTaskIndex method
and deleted redundant variable taskNumber.
Also modified the test case in accordance with the string updates made

commitResults.messageTitle: Final code cleanup for Level-6
Implement the basic operations for writing to a file
commitResults.messageBody: Added class FileHandler to take control of the file writing operations

commitResults.messageTitle: Save tasks
commitResults.messageBody:
- Added function to load data (retrieve and decipher info to store in task array)
  from the text file whenever the chatbot starts up
- Added function to save all the modified changes to the text file whenever the
  user says bye and closes the program
- Rewrote the toString() method for all the task types and added an extra parameter to
  the task class to allow the program to print the task descirptions
  differently when the task is being read from the saved text file and
  when it has just been created during that session

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge branch 'branch-Level-6'
Merge branch 'branch-Level-7'
Implement changes to ensure jar file functionality
commitResults.messageBody:
The code does not save the tasks properly when running the jar file
generated from the previous commit. Therefore, added a new
method under the FileHandler class to ensure that the parent directory
and the text file for saving the task data exists before writing any data
to it. In the case where the file or the directory doesn't exist, they are
created accordingly.

commitResults.messageTitle: Create more OOP classes
Separate the different class concerns
commitResults.messageBody:
Divided the funtionalities between the different classes more strictly.
Each class such as the Parser, UI, TaskHandler and Storage can now
only access the main Fenix controller class and cannot interact with
each other as freely anymore. This helps improve modularity and in
the separation of concerns as the different classes are not as tightly
coupled anymore.
